case_name: Descendant of Ganpati Maharaj v. Descendants of Nagubai

facts.text: This appeal was filed with a certificate from the High Court of Judicature, Bombay, against the judgment and decree dated April 22, 1949, in First Appeal No. 403 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal with a certificate of the High Court of Judicature, Bombay, has been filed against the judgment and decree of the Court dated April 22, 1949, in First Appeal No. 403 of 1945,

facts.text: The trial court judgment was delivered by the Civil Judge, Senior Division, Nasik, in Special Suit No. 5 of 1943 on August 14, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: confirming the judgment and decree of the Civil Judge, Senior Division, Nasik, in Special Suit No. 5 of 1943, decided on August 14, 1945.

facts.text: The plaintiff (appellant) is the descendant of Ganpati Maharaj, devotee of Shri Venkatesh Balaji.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff, who is the appellant here, is the descendant of one Ganpati Maharaj, who was a devotee of Shri Venkatesh Balaji.

facts.text: Ganpati Maharaj died in 1701 at age 98.

anchor.surface_text: Ganpati Maharaj died in 1701 at the ripe age of 98.

facts.text: When Ganpati Maharaj was 72, he had a dream revealing an image of Venkatesh Balaji in river Tambraparni in Tirunelveli District.

anchor.surface_text: When Ganpati Maharaj was 72 years old, it was vouchsafed to him in a dream that an image of Venkatesh Balaji would be found by him in river Tambraparni in Tirunelveli District.

facts.text: Ganpati Maharaj found the image, brought it to Junnar in Poona District, and installed it.

anchor.surface_text: He found the image, brought it to his house in Junnar  Poona District  and installed it.

facts.text: Ganpati Maharaj left behind three sons and a daughter upon death; eldest son Timmayya was 12 years old.

anchor.surface_text: and when he died, he left behind him three sons and a daughter. His eldest son, Timmayya, at the time of his death was 12 years old.

facts.text: Timmayya succeeded Ganpati Maharaj and died in 1768 at age 79.

anchor.surface_text: Timmayya succeeded Ganpati Maharaj and lived till 1768, when he died at the ripe age of 79.

facts.text: During Timmayya's lifetime, he obtained several properties as presents and gifts; suit concerns those properties in plaint schedules.

anchor.surface_text: During his lifetime, Timmayya obtained several properties as presents and gifts. The present suit companycerns those properties which are described in the schedules attached to the plaint.

facts.text: Appellant is direct descendant of Ganpati in eldest male line; respondents 1 to 4 are descendants from Ganpati's daughter Nagubai.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the direct descendants of Ganpati in the eldest male line, and respondents 1 to 4 are the descendants from Ganpatis daughter, Nagubai.

facts.text: On April 23, 1942, first four respondents applied to District Court under s.3 of Charitable and Religious Trusts Act, 1920 against appellant and two others for particulars of properties and accounts.

anchor.surface_text: On April 23, 1942, the first four respondents made an application to the District Court under s. 3 of the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act, 1920  No. 14 of 1920 , hereinafter called the Act, against the appellant and two others asking that the appellant be directed to furnish full particulars of the properties and their application and for accounts of the income as also of the properties during the three preceding years.

facts.text: Appellant denied existence of trust, claimed idol and properties as private, undertook to file suit under s.5(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in reply denied that there was a trust, much less a public trust, and claimed the idol and the properties as private. He understook to bring a suit under s. 5 3  of the Act,

facts.text: Suit filed on March 21, 1943 claiming three declarations that no trust exists, or if exists not public, and defendants have no right over deity or properties.

anchor.surface_text: and the suit out of which the present appeal arises, was filed on March 21, 1943. He claimed in the suit three declarations, which were as follows It may be declared that Shri Vyankatesh Balaji Deity and Shri Vyankatesh Balaji Sansthan are number legal trust as alleged by the Defendants and their nature also is number such as alleged by the Defendants.

facts.text: Trial Judge decided all issues against appellant, held properties not private, deity owner of public religious charitable trust, appellant hereditary shebait.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge decided all the issues against the appellant. He held that the suit properties were number the personal or private properties of the appellant, that the plaintiff was estopped from making such a claim, that the deity itself was number a family or private deity, and that the deity Shri Venkatesh Balaji was the owner of the properties, and that there was a public, religious and charitable trust in respect of them.

facts.text: High Court dismissed appeal, modified costs to one set, granted certificate under Art. 133 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court  Rajadhyaksha and Chainani, JJ.  , dismissed the appeal but modified the order about companyts, directing that only one set of companyts be paid to the defendants in the suit. ... They, however, granted a certificate of fitness under Art. 133 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Deity moved from Junnar to Nasik in lifetime of Timmayya's son due to dream warning.

anchor.surface_text: As we have stated earlier, the deity was placed in his house by Ganpati Maharaj at Junnar in Poona District. Ganpati Maharaj did number acquire any property, but in the lifetime of his son, the deity was mover from Junnar to Nasik.

facts.text: Bapaji Buva obtained plot from Peshwa near Godavari at Nasik, built temple.

anchor.surface_text: After Timmayya died his eldest son, Bapaji Buva, obtained a plot of land in gift from the Peshwa near the bank of the Godavari river at Nasik and built a temple on it.

facts.text: Family disputes in 1774 led to Tahanama (Ex. 121) vesting management in eldest male of senior branch.

anchor.surface_text: In 1774 family disputes arose and a Tahanama  Ex. 121  was executed, whereby the right of management was vested in the eldest male member of the senior branch of the family,

facts.text: In 1800, Tharav Yadi (Ex. 122) assigned villages for maintenance instead of cash.

anchor.surface_text: Again in 1800, further disputes took place in the family and a Tharav Yadi  Ex. 122  was drawn up. By that agreement, instead of the cash allowances for the maintenance of the branches certain villages were assigned to them.

facts.text: Inam Commission under Bombay Rent-free Estates Act, 1852 recorded villages as Devasthan inams after appeal by Damodar Maharaj.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Inam Commissioner recorded the grant of the villages under R. 3 of Sch. B to that Act as personal inams. Damodar Maharaj who was then the Pujadhikari or Sansthanik appealed to the Inam Commissioner, and companytended that the villages were number held as personal inams but were Devasthan inams ... The Inam Commissioner accepted this companytention,

facts.text: Damodar Maharaj died 1885, succeeded by Krishnarao (d.1893), then Bhagwantrao (d.1900), then appellant who attained majority 1921.

anchor.surface_text: Damodar Maharaj died in 1885, and was succeeded by Krishnarao Maharaj, who died in 1893, whose eldest son, Bhagwantrao Maharaj died in 1900 and was succeeded by the appellant, during whose minority the property was managed by a guardian appointed by Court. The appellant became major in 1921,

facts.text: Both lower courts held deity not family deity, properties constitute public religious charitable endowment.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out already, the two Courts below have companycurred in holding that the deity was number a mere family deity in which the public had numberinterest, and that the properties given to the deity companystituted a religious and charitable endowment of a public nature.

facts.text: Numerous admissions by appellant's predecessors from 1774 that properties belong to Devasthan, public right to worship.

anchor.surface_text: the two Courts below relied strongly against the appellant on the admissions made by his predecessors-in-title from 1774 onwards.

facts.text: Tahanama of 1774 (Ex.121) states villages granted for worship of deity, temple belongs to Sansthan.

anchor.surface_text: The earliest admission that the property belonged to the Devasthan and that there was numberprivate ownership is to be found in the Tahanama  Ex. 121  of the year 1774. ... It is stated there that Shrimant Pant Pradhan and other Sardars of  both  Nizam and Deccan  States  have granted in Inam villages for the purposes of Seva  worship  of Shri  deity .

facts.text: Supreme Court holds admissions and Inam records show properties as Devasthan inams, not private.

anchor.surface_text: We do number therefore find any misconstruction of the documents such as have been produced, and we hold that the admissions and the revenue records remain uncontradicted.

holdings.text: The suit properties are not the personal or private properties of the appellant but belong to the public religious and charitable trust owned by Shri Venkatesh Balaji deity.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge decided all the issues against the appellant. He held that the suit properties were not the personal or private properties of the appellant, that the plaintiff was estopped from making such a claim, that the deity itself was not a family or private deity, and that the deity Shri Venkatesh Balaji was the owner of the properties, and that there was a public, religious and charitable trust in respect of them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts concurred based on admissions, Inam records, public user; SC reviewed documents, found no misconstruction, admissions uncontradicted, failed to disprove Devasthan title.

holdings.text: There exists a public religious and charitable trust in respect of Shri Vyankatesh Balaji Deity and Sansthan to which the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act, 1920 applies.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out already, the two Courts below have concurred in holding that the deity was not a mere family deity in which the public had no interest, and that the properties given to the deity constituted a religious and charitable endowment of a public nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmed lower courts' factual finding via documentary review; admissions from 1774, Inam entries as Devasthan, public worship user as of right.

anchor.surface_text: The value to be attached to the decisions of the Inam Commissioner had come up for consideration before the Judicial Committee in a series of cases. It is sufficient to refer to only one of them. In Arunachellam Chetty v. Venkatachellapathi Guru Swamigal  1919  L.R. 46 I.A. 204, the Judicial Committee while dealing with the Inam Register for the year 1864 which had been produced for their inspection, attached the utmost importance to it.
